result.execSummary:
The defendant Charles R. Hultman, #362037 was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Charles R. Hultman, #362037 is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Charles R. Hultman, #362037 was found guilty of Felon Possess Firearm, a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 941.29(2)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
May petition for early discharge after 1.5 years. 
Must report to Probation once released.

miscConds.notes: Restitution of $560.00 plus 10% surcharge of $56.00 for a total of $616.00. Payable to Probation while on probation. Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment.
Must provide DNA sample and pay the $250.00 DNA surcharge to Probation while on Probation. Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment.

Not to have contact with: Jeffrey Hanvelt.
No illegal substances.

No firearms, cannot vote until civil rights restored, cannot hold elected office, other civil rights may be lost until restored, no body armor, if not US citizen face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.

timeConds.notes:
Conditional time. 
Subject to work release. 
Not eligible for Good time.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: 15CF188 and Barron County case 15CF189

superMiscConds.notes: May not possess or use firearms and, if considered a violent felony, no body armor.

Not to possess or use drugs or drug paraphernalia.  

Cannot vote until civil rights restored, cannot hold elected office, other civil rights may be lost until restored. If not a US citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.

All outstanding financial obligations to be paid through DOC while incarcerated or on supervision.  Failure to pay will be reduced to a civil judgment made payable to the Clerk of Court's Office and subject to tax intercept and other collection efforts.
